examples.sentence: When the favor wasn't asked for
Use てあげる in questions/offers more than statements
Simply omit it when talking about past actions
Use てくれる when appropriate (when someone did for you)
〜てくれる (te-kureru) - Someone does for me
〜てもらう (te-morau) - I have someone do
あげる/やる/さしあげる - Giving verbs
Direction of Actions - Perspective in Japanese

sections.heading: What is 〜てあげる (te-ageru)?
sections.content:
〜てあげる means "to do something for someone" with the nuance that the speaker is doing a favor or helping someone. It emphasizes the action being done for another person's benefit.

[Verb te-form] + あげる 教えてあげる "teach (for someone)" 手伝ってあげる "help (for someone)"

children.heading: Basic Pattern
children.content: Verb (te-form) + あげる Plain: 〜てあげる Polite: 〜てあげます 作ってあげる / 作ってあげます "make (for someone)" 送ってあげる / 送ってあげます "send/take (for someone)"

children.heading: Doing a Favor
children.content:
あげる (to give) + action = doing an action as a favor for someone.

本を貸してあげる "lend a book (for someone)" 宿題を手伝ってあげる "help with homework (for someone)" 教えてあげる "teach (for someone)"

children.heading: に or のために
children.content:
The person receiving the benefit is marked with に or のために.

友達に教えてあげる "teach (for) a friend" 弟のために作ってあげる "make (for) my younger brother" 彼女に買ってあげた "bought (for) her"

children.heading: Giving Actions Diagram
children.content: 私/We (giver) → 他の人 (receiver) てあげる "I do something for them"

children.heading: Key Points
children.content:
Speaker is doing the action Action benefits someone else Direction: from speaker/in-group to others

私は弟に本を買ってあげた "I bought a book for my younger brother" 母が妹にケーキを作ってあげた "Mom made a cake for my younger sister"

children.heading: あげる (Neutral)
children.content: 手伝ってあげる "I'll help (you/them)"

children.heading: さしあげる (Humble/Honorific)
children.content:
Used when doing something for someone of higher status.

説明してさしあげます "I'll explain (for you - honorific)" お持ちしてさしあげましょうか "Shall I carry it (for you - honorific)?"

children.heading: Offering Help
children.content: 手伝ってあげようか？ "Shall I help you?" 教えてあげましょうか？ "Shall I teach you?" 作ってあげる "I'll make it for you"

children.heading: Past Actions
children.content: 弟に本を買ってあげた "I bought a book for my younger brother" 友達を駅まで送ってあげた "I took my friend to the station" 母に料理を作ってあげた "I cooked for my mother"

children.heading: Negative Form
children.content: 教えてあげない "I won't teach (you/them)" 手伝ってあげられない "I can't help (you/them)"

children.heading: Can Sound Condescending
children.content:
てあげる can sound patronizing if used inappropriately, especially:

To superiors To strangers When the favor wasn't asked for

Less appropriate: 先生に教えてあげた ❌ "I taught the teacher" (sounds condescending) Better: 先生に教えた ✓ "I taught the teacher" Or with honorific: 先生にお教えした ✓ "I taught the teacher (humble)"

children.heading: Better in Questions/Offers
children.content:
てあげる is safer when offering help rather than stating you did something.

Safer (offer): 手伝ってあげようか？ ✓ "Shall I help you?" Can sound arrogant: 手伝ってあげた ⚠️ "I helped you" (can imply superiority)

sections.heading: Common Verbs with てあげる

children.heading: Helping Actions
children.content: 手伝ってあげる - help (for someone) 助けてあげる - save/rescue (for someone) 教えてあげる - teach (for someone) 説明してあげる - explain (for someone)

children.heading: Doing Things
children.content: 作ってあげる - make (for someone) 買ってあげる - buy (for someone) 送ってあげる - take/send (for someone) 見せてあげる - show (for someone)

children.heading: Communication
children.content: 話してあげる - tell (for someone) 読んであげる - read (for someone) 書いてあげる - write (for someone)

children.heading: てあげる vs てくれる vs てもらう
children.content: てあげる: I do for others 私が友達に教えてあげた "I taught my friend" てくれる: Others do for me 友達が（私に）教えてくれた "My friend taught me" てもらう: I have someone do 私は友達に教えてもらった "I had my friend teach me / My friend taught me"

children.heading: Example 1: Offering Help
children.content: A: 重そうだね "That looks heavy" B: 持ってあげようか？ "Shall I carry it for you?" A: ありがとう！お願い "Thanks! Please do"

children.heading: Example 2: Talking About Past Help
children.content: A: 宿題できた？ "Did you finish your homework?" B: うん、兄が教えてくれたんだ "Yeah, my brother taught me" (Note: Using てくれる, not てあげる) A: いいお兄さんだね "What a nice brother"

children.heading: Example 3: Between Friends
children.content: A: これ、どうやって使うの？ "How do you use this?" B: 教えてあげる "I'll teach you" A: ありがとう！ "Thanks!"

children.heading: Mistake 1: Using with superiors
children.content: Wrong: 先生に教えてあげた ❌ Better: 先生に教えた ✓ Or: 先生にお教えした ✓ "I taught the teacher"

children.heading: Mistake 2: Sounding too proud
children.content: Can sound arrogant: 私が全部やってあげた ⚠️ "I did everything for them" More humble: 私が全部やった ✓ "I did everything"

children.heading: Mistake 3: Wrong particle
children.content: Wrong: 友達を教えてあげた ❌ Right: 友達に教えてあげた ✓ "I taught my friend"

children.heading: Mistake 4: Confusing direction
children.content: Context: Someone helped you Wrong: 友達が私に教えてあげた ❌ Right: 友達が私に教えてくれた ✓ "My friend taught me"

sections.heading: When to Avoid てあげる

children.heading: With Superiors
children.content: Don't use: 社長に説明してあげた ❌ Better: 社長に説明した/ご説明した ✓ "I explained to the president"

children.heading: When Not Really a Favor
children.content: Unnatural: ご飯を食べてあげた ❌ Natural: ご飯を食べた ✓ "I ate a meal"

children.heading: In Formal Writing
children.content:
Often better to use simpler forms in formal contexts.

Casual: 手伝ってあげました Formal: お手伝いしました/ご協力しました "I helped/assisted"

children.heading: 〜てあげようか？ (Shall I...?)
children.content:
Offering to do something.

手伝ってあげようか？ "Shall I help you?" 教えてあげようか？ "Shall I teach you?" やってあげようか？ "Shall I do it for you?"

children.heading: 〜てあげたい (want to do for)
children.content: 何かしてあげたい "I want to do something for them" 助けてあげたい "I want to help them"

children.heading: 〜てあげられない (can't do for)
children.content: 今は手伝ってあげられない "I can't help now" お金がないから、買ってあげられない "I can't buy it because I have no money"

sections.heading: With Family and Close Relationships
sections.content:
てあげる is more natural when talking about helping family members or close friends, especially those younger or of equal/lower status.

Natural contexts: 弟に本を買ってあげた "I bought a book for my younger brother" 子供に絵本を読んであげる "I read a picture book to my child" 友達を空港まで送ってあげた "I took my friend to the airport"

children.heading: Casual (あげる)
children.content: 教えてあげる "I'll teach you" 手伝ってあげるよ "I'll help you"

children.heading: Polite (あげます)
children.content: 教えてあげます "I'll teach you" 手伝ってあげましょうか "Shall I help you?"

children.heading: Honorific (さしあげる)
children.content: ご説明してさしあげます "I'll explain (for you - honorific)" お手伝いしてさしあげましょうか "Shall I help you? (honorific)"

children.heading: Japanese Perspective on Giving
children.content:
In Japanese culture, explicitly stating you did something for someone can sound boastful. Native speakers often:

Use てあげる in questions/offers more than statements Simply omit it when talking about past actions Use てくれる when appropriate (when someone did for you)

More humble: 手伝った "I helped" More explicit (can sound proud): 手伝ってあげた "I helped (for them)"

children.heading: Offers
children.content: 手伝ってあげましょうか？ "Shall I help you?" 教えてあげようか？ "Shall I teach you?" 持ってあげる "I'll carry it for you" 作ってあげます "I'll make it for you"

children.heading: Past Actions
children.content: 弟に本を買ってあげた "I bought a book for my younger brother" 妹を駅まで送ってあげた "I took my younger sister to the station" 友達に日本語を教えてあげた "I taught Japanese to my friend"

children.heading: With Children/Pets
children.content: 子供に絵本を読んであげる "I read a picture book to my child" 犬に餌をあげる "I feed the dog" 赤ちゃんをお風呂に入れてあげる "I bathe the baby"

children.heading: Questions
children.content: 何をしてあげようか？ "What shall I do for you?" どこまで送ってあげようか？ "How far shall I take you?" 何か買ってあげようか？ "Shall I buy you something?"
